questions.text: Nerve roots involved in Erb's palsy?
questions.solution:
Erb-Duchenne Palsy Upper lesions of the brachial plexus are injuries resulting from excessive displacement of the head to the opposite side and depression of the shoulder on the same side. This causes excessive traction or even tearing of C5 and C6 roots of the plexus. It occurs in the new-born during a difficult delivery or in adults after a blow to or fall on the shoulder. The suprascapular nerve, the nerve to the subclavius, and the musculocutaneous and axillary nerves all possess nerve fibers derived from C5 and C6 roots and will therefore be functionless.
The following muscles will consequently be paralyzed: the supraspinatus (abductor of the shoulder) and infraspinatus (lateral rotator of the shoulder); the subclavius (depresses the clavicle); the biceps brachii (supinator of the forearm, flexor of the elbow, weak flexor of the shoulder) and the greater part of the brachialis (flexor of the elbow) and the coracobrachialis (flexes the shoulder); and the deltoid (abductor of the shoulder) and the teres minor (lateral rotator of the shoulder).
Thus, the limb will hang limply by the side, medially rotated by the unopposed sternocostal part of the pectoralis major; the forearm will be pronated because of loss of the action of the biceps.
The position of the upper limb in this condition has been likened to that of a porter or waiter hinting for a tip. In addition, there will be a that of a porter or waiter hinting for a tip. In addition, there will be a loss of sensation down the lateral side of the arm.
Treatment The three most common treatments from Erb's Palsy are: Nerve transfers (usually from the opposite leg), subscapularis releases and latissimus dorsi tendon transfers.

questions.text: Which one of the mechanisms enlisted below of autoimmunity is mainly responsible for the development of rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
• Molecular mimicry in rheumatic fever:
    • antibodies to M protein of streptococci cross-react with myosin, laminin, and other matrix proteins, and also with neuronal antigens → Deposition of such autoantibodies in heart → initiation of inflammatory response → if penetration into brain → results in Sydenham chorea.

questions.text: A patient presents with defective adduction of the hip joint and pains in the hip and knee joint. Which nerve is involved?
questions.solution: Obturator nerve Adductors of the thigh are mainly supplied by the obturator nerve. A disease in the hip joint may cause referred pain in the knee & medial thigh because of their common nerve supply by the obturator nerve.

questions.text: Number of lobes in the breast?
questions.solution: The breast (mammary gland) is a modified sweat gland present in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region. It consists of 15-20 lobes. Vertically it extends from the 2nd to 6th ribs at the midclavicular line and the horizontal extent is from sternal margin to midaxillary line at the level of the 4th rib.

questions.text: A 20-year-old alcoholic malnourished patient presented to hospital with respiratory distress. His pulse was 112/minute. Patient had edema, hypertension, systolic murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral crepitations were felt in the lungs. A diagnosis of congestive high output cardiac failure was made. Which vitamin is deficient?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B 1 – water soluble vitamin

  • It has a specific coenzyme TPP (thiamine pyrophosphate) this help in carbohydrate metabolism .
  • TPP Dependent enzyme
  1. pyruvate dehydrogenase - conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA.
  2. alpha -Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase – CTA CYCLE
  3. Transketolase - (HMP shunt)
  4. The branched chain ALPHA - keto acid dehydrogenase -: oxidative decarboxylation pyrophosphate of branched chain amino acids.
  • RDA (Recommended dietary allowance)
    • Adult – 1 – 1.5 mg/day
    • Children – 0.7 – 1.2 mg /day
  • The requirement increases in pregnancy and lactation (2 mg/ day), old age and alcoholism.
  • Deficiency of vitamin b 1 is known as beriberi In adults, two types of beri-beri
  • WET BERI – BERI - This is characterized by edema of legs, face, trunk and serous cavities.
    • Dyspnoea and palpitation are present
    • The systolic blood pressure is elevated while diastolic is decreased
    • Pulse is fast and bouncing
    • Death is due to heart failure
  • Dry beri-beri - This is associated with neurological manifestations resulting in peripheral neuritis.
    • edema is not seen
    • muscle become week so patient has difficulty in walking.
  • Infantile beri-beri
    • infant born to mother who is suffering from thiamine deficiency
    • Brest milk is containing low thiamine
    • Sleeplessness, vomiting, convulsions
    • Bouts of screaming
    • resembles to abdominal colic
    • These all symptoms are due cardiac dilation
    • Death occurs suddenly due to heart failure
  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy
    • Seen in chronic alcoholics
    • insufficient intake or impaired intestinal absorption of thiamine will lead to this syndrome
    • Symptoms of Wernicke’s encephalopathy
  1. G-Global confusion
  2. O-Ophthalmoplegia
  3. A-Ataxia
  • Korsakoff syndrome – chronic neurological complication
  1. Amnesia - mainly anterograde amnesia
  2. Confabulations – false story and honest lying
  • Thiamine Nutritional Status Can Be Assessed by Erythrocyte Transketolase Activity

questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled child with coarse facial features large tongue, short stature to age, joint stiffness, inguinal hernia came to the OPD. On examination clouded cornea and bullet shaped middle phalanx was seen. Deficiency of which enzyme is implicated in such case?
questions.solution:
All the clinical features in question indicate Gargoylism i.e., Hurler’s disease.

There is deficiency of α-L-iduronidase due to which excess of glycosaminoglycans accumulate. Clinical features of Hurler’s disease:

  • Inguinal hernia
  • Reilly Body Inclusions i.e. coarse dark granules surrounded by a clear zone, present in neutrophils.
  • Most severe MPS.
  • Corneal clouding present.

questions.text: Normal glucose tolerance is?

choices.text: Fasting plasma glucose <126 mg/dL following an oral glucose challenge
Fasting plasma glucose <100 mg/dL, hemoglobin A1C <5.6%

questions.solution:
• Glucose tolerance:
    • Three categories:
  1. normal glucose tolerance (fasting plasma glucose <100 mg/dL, plasma glucose <140 mg/dL after an oral glucose challenge, and hemoglobin A1C <5.6%)
  2. impaired glucose homeostasis (fasting plasma glucose of 100–125 mmol/dL or a plasma glucose of 140–199 following an oral glucose tolerance test or hemoglobin A1C of 5.7%–6.4%)
  3. diabetes mellitus (fasting plasma glucose >126 mg/dL, glucose of 200 mg/dL after an oral glucose tolerance test, or hemoglobin A1C ≥6.5%

questions.text: Structure that lies outside the femoral sheath?
questions.solution:
Femoral sheath is a funnel-shaped fascial prolongation around the proximal part of femoral vessels, situated in the femoral triangle, below the inguinal ligament. It is 3-4 cm long. It is formed by fascia iliaca.
The femoral sheath is divided into 3 separate fascial compartments by septa
Lateral compartment:- It contains the femoral artery and femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve.
Intermediate compartment:- Femoral vein. Medial compartment (femoral canal):- It is conical in shape, wider above and narrow below. The wider upper opening is known as a femoral ring, which is potentially a weak point in the lower abdomen and is the site for a femoral hernia.
Femoral ring is bounded: Anteriorly by the inguinal ligament, medially by lacunar ligament, posteriorly by pectineus with its covering fascia, and laterally by septum separating it from the femoral vein.
Femoral canal contains lymph nodes of Cloquet or Rosenmuller and lymphatics.

questions.text: The renal ability to excrete concentrated urine will rise if:

choices.text: Permeability of the collecting duct to H2O increases
Rate of flow of filtrate through the loop of Henle rises
Na-K pump activity in the loop of Henle decreases

questions.text: Enzymes perform catalysis by changing the activation energy of a reaction. The term activation energy actually is the difference between free energies of:
questions.solution:
• For a substrate to become product, it goes to a transition state (S‡) which is a fleeting, momentary, unstable chemical species.
  • It is neither substrate nor product. It has the highest free energy in a reaction coordinate diagram. This creates an energy barrier for substrate to become a product. This energy is known as activation energy.
  • ΔGcatand ΔGuncatis the activation energy (see fig). It is free energy difference between substrate and that of the transition state

Fig: Gibb’s Free Energy graph for enzyme catalyzed and enzyme uncatalyzed reaction.On X- axis, reaction progress taken (i.e. S getting converted to P). For any spontaneous reaction, S has more free energy as compared to P. For S to be converted to P, first S has to acquire Activation energy (ΔG uncatalyzed) and reach high energy state (Transition state). Only then it can be converted to P.

Note:Even if the substrate to product formation is exergonic, substrate to transition state formation is always endergonic.

questions.text: When the plasma glucose falls below 80–85 mg/dL, which one of the following physiologic changes is the first to occur?
questions.solution:
• Maintenance of euglycemia:
  1. decrease in insulin secretion
  2. Increase in hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  3. Decreased peripheral glucose utilization.
  4. Glucagon secretion
  5. Further stimulation of hepatic gluconeogenesis.
  6. Secretion of Epinephrine, Cortisol and growth hormone (after 4 hours of hypoglycemia).

questions.text: Mean QRS vectors in the frontal electrocardiographic plane are matched appropriately to their designation in which one of the following?
Which of the following is regarded as the 1st substrate of TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
TCA cycle is controlled by:

1. Energy status of the cell:

a. Low cellular ATP ® TCA activity High; High cellular ATP → TCA activity low.

2. Availability of oxaloacetate (not acetyl CoA)

  1. OAA is regarded as carrier and 1st substrate of TCA cycle
  2. OAA also has catalytic role in TCA cycle. OAA is regenerated in each round of TCA so, TCA is a considered as a cycle and not a pathway

questions.text: In a patient who requires complete resection of the pituitary gland after the diagnosis of a pituitary tumor, which of the following listed functions of adrenal gland will be preserved immediately postoperatively?

choices.text: Morning peak of plasma cortisol level
Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia

questions.solution:
• 3 major functions of adrenal gland:
  1. glucocorticoid synthesis (controlled by the pituitary secretion of ACTH)
  2. aldosterone synthesis (primary stimulus for RAAS, independent of the pituitary)
  3. androgen precursor synthesis.
  • Hence, morning cortisol secretion and release of cortisol in response to stress- regulated by the pituitary gland
  • Regulation of sodium retention + potassium excretion by aldosterone: independent of pituitary, is preserved in this patient.

questions.text: Medium used for antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
• Antibiotic sensitivity testing is carried out to determine an appropriate antibiotic to be used for a particular strain isolated from clinical specimens.
  • Antibiotic testing can be carried out by two broad methods :
  1. Disc diffusion tests
  2. Dilution tests

Disc diffusion tests

  • There are the most commonly used methods to determine antibiotic susceptibility. Discs impregnated with a known concentration of antibiotics and are placed on the culture medium that has been inoculated with a culture of the bacterium to be tested.
  • Antibiotic sensitivity is determined by the zone of inhibition of bacterial growth around the disc.
  • Selection of media Medium that supports both test and control strains is selected for carrying out antibiotic susceptibility testing.
  • For example: Muller-Hinton agar is used for gram-negative bacilli and Staphylococcus spp. Blood agar is used for streptococcus spp and Enterococcus spp.
  • Chocolate agar is used for Haemophilus influenza Wellcotest medium uses antibiotics sulfonamide and cotrimoxazole
  • Mueller -Hinton agar is the most commonly used medium for antibiotic sensitivity testing Type of disc diffusion test.
  • Disc diffusion tests are the following types :
  1. Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method - most commonly used.
  2. Stoke disc diffusion method iii) Primary disc diffusion test

questions.text: In a vaccine vial monitor the following reading shown in the image indicates which of the following options?
questions.solution:
Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM)
• Description: A simple tool (sticker on OPV vial) which enables vaccinator to know ‘whether vaccine is potent’ at the time of administration
• Mandatory since 1998 for quality assurance

WHO Grading of VVM (OPV) – How to read a VVM


• Inner square is lighter than outer circle. If the expiry date has not been passed, use the vaccine.


• At a later time, inner square is lighter than outer circle. If the expiry date has not been passed, use the vaccine.


• Discard point : Inner square matches colour of outside circle. Do not use the vaccine. Inform your supervisor.


• Beyond the discard point : Inner square darker than outer circle. Do not use the vaccine. Inform your supervisor.

questions.text: Frozen phenomenon is used for?
questions.solution: Some psychrophilic bacteria can grow at 0°C, but subzero temperatures will inhibit the metabolism of microorganisms in general. Freezing is commonly used to preserve foods, drugs, and laboratory specimens because it effectively stops microbial growth. However, the subzero temperature may not kill microorganisms (especially psychrophilic) and may in fact preserve them along with the material being frozen. This phenomenon has been used by microbiologists to store and preserve microorganisms

questions.text: Listeria resists phagocytosis in phagosomes (phagolysosomes) due to?

  • *The most important determinant of pathogenesis k listeriolysin O (LLO), A beta- hemolysin.
  • LLO causes lysis of membrane of phagosomes within phagocytes and helps in the intracellular survival of L monocytogenes. * Iron is an important virulence factor.
  • Listeria produces siderophores and are able to obtain iron from transferrin.
  • Immunity to listeria is primary cell-mediated.
  • Immunity can be transferred by sensitized lymphocytes but not by antibodies

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. After stabilising the patient, he was prescribed Warfarin and Clopidogrel along with other drugs. What are the microsomal enzymes that metabolize these drugs respectively?

questions.text: You are an Medical officer posted for post diaster management after a flood in a rural area. If you suspect that a well may be contaminated by germs from flood waters or another source, the recommended residual chlorine level for disinfecting is:
questions.solution:
CHLORINATION OF WATER:
• Disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to
Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) - Main role in disinfection
Hypochlorite ions (OCl) - Minor role in disinfection
Chlorine has a residual germicidal effect (and not Ozone or UV rays): Provides a margin of safety against subsequent microbial contamination, as may occur during storage and distribution

• Phases of Chlorination
Phase I: Formation of chloramines
Phase II: Destruction of chloramines
Phase III: Appearance of break-point
Phase IV: Accumulation of free residual chlorine

• Recommended contact period of free residual chlorine in water: 1 hour

Level of free residual chlorine (FRC) recommended:

Water type Recommended Residual chlorine level Contact period
Drinking water >0.5 mg per litre (ppm) 1 hour
Water bodies, post disaster >0.7 mg per litre (ppm) 1 hour
Swimming pool sanitation >1.0 mg per litre (ppm) 1 hour


• The correct dose of chlorine to be applied: Chlorine demand + FRC 0.5 mg per litre.

questions.text: A man, with history of alcoholism assaulted his neighbor. On taking history, he admitted stopping alcohol 4 days ago, and a diagnosis of delirium tremens was made. What is the most appropriate punishment for the murderer?

choices.text: Patient is half responsible for the act
Patient is not responsible under IPC 84 for his act

questions.solution:
Delirium Tremens - This results from the long continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in the chronic alcoholics due to Sudden withdrawal of alcohol.
• It typically begins 72-96 hrs after the last drink.
There is acute attack of insanity in which the main symptoms are
• Coarse muscular tremors of face, tongue and hands
• Insomnia
• Restlessness
• Loss of memory
• Uncontrollable fear
• Tendency to commit suicide, homicide or violent assault or to cause damage to the property
• Disorientation to time and place and a peculiar kind of delirium of horrors owing to hallucinations of the sight and hearing.
• It is considered unsoundness of mind and not intoxication, so section 84 IPC will be applied.
• A person in delirium is not responsible for his criminal acts according to section 84 IPC.
Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind
• Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
• Note: 84 IPC is the version obtained from McNaughten rule and is used in India as IPC for the act of a person of unsound mind.

questions.text: 65-year-old man presents with excessive cold intolerance, hypertension and slow ankle jerks. He is also having hypertension. Thyroid function test shows TSH of 16 IUI L and low T3 and T4. What is appropriate management?

choices.text: Start at levothyroxine dose of 25 ug and increase dose gradually
Start at levothyroxine dose of 100 ug and decrease dose gradually
Start levothyroxine dose of 100 ug and increase dose gradually
Start levothyroxine dose of 25 ug and decrease dose gradually

questions.solution:
• Given history is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism i.e thyroid gland is unable to produce thyroid hormone. Thus, by feedback mechanism, TSH is increased [normal TSH levels goes upto 5.5]
  • In old age, angina/ heart diseases could be present. Levothyroxine increases the oxygen consumption of the heart.
  • Thus, if we give high dose of levo-thyroxine, it increases oxygen consumption of the heart to such a level that it can trigger angina
  • Thus, start the pt. with low dose levo-thyroxine [I.e 25ug] & then gradually increase [50ug, 80ug,100ug etc] the dose by repeating the thyroid function tests after 2-4 weeks
  • Never increase the dose beyond 100ug as it may trigger angina
  • T3 is Liothyronine. It is given in endocrine emergency with hypothyroidism k/a myxedema coma [characterized by hypothermia]

questions.text: 45-year-old Male with HbA1C= 8% comes to ER with hemiplegia 8 hours prior to consult. NCCT head is normal. BP = 198/110 mm Hg. Which of the following intervention is best scheduled for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Clinical diagnosis of this pt. is Acute ischemic stroke
  • Even though CT-head is normal, hemiplegia points towards ischemic stroke, as findings of CT- scan takes some time to appear [may be 12hrs]
  • CT-scan is mainly done to rule out hemorrhagic stroke
  • CT-angiography/ DW-MRI can be done in these pts
  • If a person is suffering from ischemic stroke, 1st thing is to pick up whether the pt. is candidate for thrombolysis/ not
  • If the pt. Is candidate for thrombolysis, it should be done within 4.5 hrs of onset of symptoms [I.e window period]
  • As the pt. is having symptoms from past 8hrs [out of window period], he isn’t the candidate for thrombolysis
  • If the pt. is brought within the window period, thrombolysis is done only if the BP is <185/110 mm of Hg
  • If the BP is >185/110 mm of Hg in candidates suitable for thrombolysis, IV Nicardipine or Labetalol is used to decrease the BP
  • One of the major side effects of thrombolysis is bleeding.
  • In candidates where thrombolysis is not done, BP should be lowered only if it is > 220/130 mm of Hg
  • As the given pt. isn’t candidate for thrombolysis, t-PA & IV labetalol isn’t required
  • Sublingual nifedipine causes precipitous/ unpredictable fall of BP, which may result in cerebral ischemia & worsening of the pt.
  • Thus, observation & monitoring should be done in this pt

questions.text: A man’s HIV test is positive, but he has no signs or symptoms of AIDS. In 25% of patients with a positive HIV test, which one of the following psychiatric diagnoses may develop?
questions.solution: • Patients receiving a positive HIV test may need counseling for a wide variety of symptoms, including anxi- ety and depression, a syndrome like PTSD, concern about minor physical symptoms, and adjustment disorders, the latter of which can occur in as many as 25% of those given a positive diagnosis. Other issues may be wor- ries about telling friends and family, issues of guilt and self-esteem, worries about financial and work considerations, and the future of the medical condition itself.

questions.text: A patient is having a sudden exacerbation of dyspnea and can't talk. On chest auscultation, prolonged expiration is noted. ABG report shows pH= 7.3, PCO2= 84 mm Hg, HCO3=33 meq/L. Which of the following intervention should be done?
questions.solution:
• Low pH and elevated Pco2 is suggestive of respiratory acidosis
  • A compensatory increase of bicarbonate levels is seen
  • Thus, the pt is suffering from Partially compensated respiratory acidosis
  • Non-invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation is used in the treatment of this pt to prevent asterixis/ Co2 narcosis

Other options

  • Intravenous soda bicarbonate is used to correct Metabolic acidosis, in which pH, PCo2 & Bicarbonate levels are low
  • Ammonium chloride is used to correct Metabolic alkalosis in which pH [>7.45], PCo2 & Bicarbonate levels [>26] are high
  • Fluid resuscitation is done in pts with hypovolemic shock [I.e gunshot injury/ bleeding varices/ perforated ulcer etc]

    (BBS also has metaphyseal corner#)

Chronic SubduralHematoma

questions.text:
A patient underwent cataract surgery and after 3 days he came to ER with the following clinical picture.

Which of the following will not be done to manage this case?
questions.solution:
• The image shown demonstrates circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, anterior chamber inflammation with hypopyon. With history of cataract surgery, the first diagnosis should be post-operative endophthalmitis.
  • Post-operative endophthalmitis is intraocular inflammation secondary to an infection following intra-ocular surgery.

MANAGEMENT:

  • Antimicrobial Therapy
    • Intravitreal therapy
      • Antibiotics - Vancomycin, Amikacin, Ceftazidime
      • Antifungals - Amphotericin B Topical/subconjunctival antibiotics Systemic (intravenous) antibiotics do not have a role
  • Supportive therapy - Topical cycloplegics, Anti-glaucoma medication
    • Surgical - Core and total vitrectomy - early surgical intervention has shown to give better outcome

questions.text: A 45 year old man presented to the emergency room after a bike accident and injuring his perineum. He want to urinate but unable to do so, and urethral meatus is filled with blood, as well as significant swelling of scrotum and penis. What is the possible site of injury?
questions.solution:
Anterior Urethral Injuries

  • MC injured anterior urethral part - bulbar part of urethra

Clinical features :

  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at meatus
  • Perineal Hematoma - involves shaft & Bilateral scrotum (butterfly shaped)

Treatment

  • Suprapubic cystotomy performed followed by delayed repair

questions.text: Patient presents with worst headache of his life. CT head shows evidence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• ‘Worst headache of his life’ is a characteristic feature of sub arachnoid hemorrhage.
  • Sylvian fissure separates parietal from temporal lobe.
  • Hyperdense area (white area) is present in the sylvian fissure, which is suggestive of SAH
  • Middle cerebral artery has been hampered which leads to this manifestation.

Other options

  • Encephalitis presents with altered sensorium
  • Meningitis presents with nuchal rigidity
  • Subdural hemorrhage mostly have hx of falling in the bathroom

questions.text: Following can be used for emergency contraception, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Emergency Contraceptives

  • Levonorgestrel (POP): 1 dose 1.5 mg within 72 hrs (DOC)
  • Copper IUDs ( NOT THE DOC ):Insertion within 5 days
  • Ulipristal acetate (SPRM) : 30 mg orally within 120 hours
  • Ethinyl estradiol 50 µg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg (COC) : 2 tab stat and 2 after 12 hour
  • Mifepristone RU 486 (PA) : 25 to 100 mg single dose

Danazol also will act as a contraceptive, however it must not be used as failure to prevent pregnancy can lead to a virilised female fetus

questions.text: which is the Most common benign cardiac tumor?
questions.solution:
• Atrial myxoma is the most common benign cardiac tumor.
  • It usually presents with symptoms of valvular obstruction (mural or tricuspid valve).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male admitted to the ICU, with long bone fracture after a motor vehicle accident, and patient was hemodynamically unstable. Dyspnea occured after two days, with petechial rash over the skin. Diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• RTA presenting long bone fractures + respiratory distress +petechiae / hemorrhage in brain suggests : fat embolism syndrome

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

  • Generally associated with displaced long bone fractures of lower extremities
  • Occurs in 0.5-3.05% of cases
  • Fat embolism will reach in the brain through a right to left cardiac shunt or through an intact pulmonary circulation in the patient without the shunt
  • Major clinical characteristics : respiratory insufficiency , neurologic symptoms , and petechial skin rash

questions.text: A young woman with SLE, that is complicated by nephropathy, hemolytic anemia, and pleuritis, recently discovered that she is pregnant. She is concerned about the effect her autoimmune disease may have on her infant. Most common cardiac complication in children born to mothers with SLE is?

    • In a structurally normal heart

questions.text: A contrast sensitivity test must be performed on a patient of glaucoma. Which of the following is not a contrast sensitivity test?
A patient has presented with features of cardiac tamponade. Which of the following is a true finding?

choices.text: Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations

questions.solution:
• Pulses paradoxus means disappearance of pulse.
  • In low pressure cardiac tamponade, pressure is only on the atria
  • Atria contributes only 30% of the filling of the ventricles. So, pulse becomes weak but it doesn’t disappear. I.e Pulses paradoxus is absent
  • Pulses paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade [high pressure], where pressure is seen in all the chambers of the heart resulting in disappearance of pulse
  • Thus, pulses paradoxus is not always seen in cardiac tamponade. It is absent in low pressure cardiac tamponade

Kussmaul sign

  • It is raise of JVP during inspiration
  • It is seen in CRR
    • Constrictive pericarditis, calcification
    • Restrictive cardiomyopathy, fibrosis
    • Right-sided congestive heart failure
  • It isn’t seen in Cardiac tamponade
    • We have large a-wave/ canoon a-wave but not tall a-wave
  • Most important diagnostic feature of cardiac tamponade is non-pulsatile elevated JVP
  • In all conditions, we can see pulsatile elevated JVP
  • But, in cardiac tamponade pressure is so high that the pulsations tend to disappear

questions.text: A 13 year old female with clinical features of shield shaped chest, short stature, widely spaced nipples and amenorrhea presented with the following Chest X-ray finding. What is the expected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of Aorta

  • Infantile – Preductal coarctation
  • Adult – Postductal coarctation
  • M >F
  • Turners syndrome female – more prone
  • Inferior rib notching is seen – If > 10 years
  • “3 sign “ – seen in CXR
  • “Reverse 3 sign “ – seen in 3-9 ribs & usually seen in 4-8 ribs
  • Inferior rib notching is seen in 3-9 ribs & usually seen in 4-8 ribs
  • Both superior & inferior rib notching can occur in hyperparathyroidism & Neurofibromatosis.

3 sign (X-ray)

Reverse 3 sign (Barium swallow)

questions.text: A 47-year-old male who is known case of HIV came to the OPD with complaints of eye pain and diminishing vision. Further evaluation and laboratory results pointed to endophthalmitis. A sample was sent for culture. Which of the following is the most common cause of endophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Candida is most common cause of endophthalmitis in AIDS patients.

Ocular Manifestations in HIV

Anterior Segment

  • MolluscumContagiousm
  • Herpes ZosterOphthalmicus
  • Kaposi Sarcoma
  • Ocular Surface SquamousNeoplasia
  • Trichomegaly
  • Dry Eyes
  • Anterior Uveitis

Ocular Manifestations In HIV

Posterior Segment

  • Acute Retinal Necrosis
  • Progressive Outer Retinal Necrosis
  • Toxoplasma
  • Candida Albicans Endophthalmitis
  • Optic Neuritis

questions.text: Following can be the cause of Hydrops fetalis, Except ?
questions.solution:
Hydrops fetalis -

    • Excessive destruction of the fetal red cells leads to severe anemia, tissue anoxemia and metabolic acidosis
    • It is accumulation of fluid in the body of the fetus in two out of three compartments: ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion
  • Most common cause of immune hydrops fetalis - Rh incompatibility
  • Others causes of hydrops fetalis
    1. Cardio vascular cause – congenital heart block ( Most common)
    2. Chromosomal cause – turner syndrome (45 XO ), triploidy , trisomies 21,18 and 13
    3. Hematological → α 4 – thalassemia (HB barts) , fetomaternal hemorrhage
    4. Infections → Parvovirus B19(mc) , syphilis , cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis Rubella, HSV

questions.text: A Young patient developed a sudden onset fever and agitated behavior for 2 days. No meningeal signs were noted. EEG shows periodic focal Temporal lobe spikes. CSF shows 40 cells with 90% lymphocytes and 10% neutrophils with elevated protein. Which of the following should be started in the patient?
questions.solution:
• When short history + Fever + Altered sensorium is given, think of viral/ bacterial etiology
  • Periodic focal Temporal lobe spikes, indicates that temporal lobe is involved
  • In given pt, CSF lymphocytes are increased [Normal count=0-4] ; which is suggestive of Tubercular/ Viral etiology
  • It isn’t Tubercular etiology, as it has the history that spans for weeks , no. of cells are furthermore & the proteins are grossly elevated in CSF I.e Cob web coagulum
  • Thus, given history is suggestive of viral etiology

Note

  • MCC of Encephalitis in India is Japanese B Encephalitis
  • MCC of encephalitis globally is HSV encephalitis
  • Herpes simplex has the prejudication to involve the temporal lobe of the brain
  • Rx: Acyclovir

Other options

  • Ceftriaxone is useful for Acute bacterial meningitis. Meningeal signs are present in this case & CSF shows > 1000 PMN/Cu.ml
  • Amphotericin B is used in Cryptococcal meningitis. History would be given on AIDS +ve pt

questions.text: 60-year-old man with complaints of early satiety, progressive pallor and chronic abdominal pain for 6 months. Bone marrow biopsy done shows band neutrophils with basophil count of 4%, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes and mature blasts of 9%. Leukocytosis and thrombocytosis was given. Which of the following is correct about presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
• History of anemia point towards Iron deficiency anemia/ hematological malignancy
  • BM biopsy is showing banded neutrophils, which are immature neutrophils
  • Basophil [scantiest blood cells] count is increased in the pt
  • Shift to left: immature cell lines are present in large amounts
  • In Chronic myeloid leukemia [CML], there will be proliferation of all the preccursor cell
  • s(myelocytes, metamyelocytes etc)
  • In AML/ ALL, there will be maturation arrest. Thus, only one cell line will be multiplied
  • Thus, Chronic history + increased basophil count + shift to left is suggestive of CML
  • Philadelphia chromosome I.e t(9,22) is involved in CML.
  • t(8,14), t(2,8), t(8,22) is seen in Burkitt’s lymphoma
    • It’s presentation is of an afroasian descent child, with jaw swelling
    • Lymph node biopsy showing starry sky appearance.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6 year old child suddenly complains of a headache and falls. In the ER: lethargic, left central facial weakness and left hemiparesis with conjugate ocular deviation to right. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute infantile hemiplegia:
    • Tthromboembolic occlusion of the middle cerebral artery
    • An acute syndrome of fever
    • Partial seizure
    • Resulting hemiparesis.

questions.text: A 40 year old female presented to the gynecologist with complaints of excess bleed for the past 3 months, with no response to medical management. USG revealed no abnormality. Next step is?
questions.solution:
Endometrial sampling is considered for those younger than 45 with

  • Chronic excess estrogen exposure (exogenous or endogenous)
  • Failed medical management
  • Persistent AUB

According to ACOG, Endometrial sampling is recommended in women older than 45 years with AUB.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with hearing loss in his left ear. Further history revealed that few days back, a cracker accidentally burst near him. From then, he could not hear normally like before. What is the first thing that you will do to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Simple funda: Always check the weber’s first in tuning fork test questions
  • Weber goes away from SNHL
  • Weber goes towards CHL

4 step method of Tuning fork test

  • Step 1: Check weber’s
  • Step 2: Check patient`s complaints
  • Step 3: Check Rinne’s negative side
  • Step 4: Rinne’s positive both sides (Then it is SNHL)

Weber’s Test

  • Tuning fork placed in the midline of vertex.
  • Sound heard in the better ear SNHL
  • Sound heard in the bad ear CHL
  • Normal is heard in the center.
  • More sensitive than Rinne’s test. (5 db)

questions.text: Correct position of sites of auscultation of heart valves is?

choices.text: A= Pulmonic, B= Aortic , C= Mitral area , D= Tricuspid area
A= Aortic , B= Pulmonic , C= Tricuspid area , D= Mitral area
A= Pulmonic, B= Aortic , C= Tricuspid area , D= Mitral area
A= Mitral , B= Aortic , C= Mitral area , D= Pulmonic area

questions.solution:
Mnemonic: PASS-- Pulmonary & Arotic stenosis are systolic murmurs.

Mnemonic: All Physicians Take Money

  • Area A: Aortic valve is present on left-hand side, but it is auscultated on the right-hand side.
  • At right 2nd intercostal space, parasternally we can auscultate to hear murmur of aortic stenosis
  • Area B: At left 2nd intercostal space, parasternally we can auscultate for murmur of pulmonary stenosis.
  • Area C: Left lower sternal border, around 4th intercostal space is a tricuspid area, where tricuspid stenosis or regurgitation is heard.
  • Area D: At 5th intercostal space, 2cm medial to the midclavicular line, mitral valve stenosis or regurgitation is auscultated.
  • ERBS POINT is located near third intercostal space.
    • Its objective is to check the splitting of S2 (S 2 has 2 components A2 and P 2 which are separated by a time lag of 30 milliseconds).
    • To check this ask the patient to hold his breath

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented with generalised pustules all over the body. The lesions started few days ago in the palms and later spread all over the body. The pain increased as the lesions increased in number. Further history revealed that the patient is taking medications for Tuberculosis. The patient also looked very dehydrated. HLA B27 was positive. What might the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pustular psoriasis
• Multiple sterile pustules develop on palm, anal, sole.
(as no infection. Only infiltration is present).
• Generalized type of pustular psoriasis k/a Von Zumbusch disease.
• If patient develops in pregnancy, it is k/a Impetigo herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis in pregnancy).

• HLA B27 → • Psoriatic arthritis
• Pustular psoriasis
• Reiter’s disease

questions.text: All are true about HCG, EXCEPT?

choices.text: It has Alpha and Beta subunits
Appears in Blood as early as 3 days after conception
Act on same receptor as LH

questions.solution:
• hCG is a glycoprotein that is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast.
• It has Alpha and Beta subunits
• hCG-αHCG is identical to theαsubunit of LH, FSH, and TSH.
• hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotropic and has little FSH activity.
• It can be detected in the blood as early as 6 days after conception.
• It appears to act on the same receptor as LH.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman in her fifth month of pregnancy complains of severe lower abdominal discomfort. The cervical os is closed on examination, and A normal intrauterine pregnancy with a 6 cm right ovarian dermoid cyst is seen on USG. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Ovarian masses in pregnancy may be symptomatic or incidentally detected on USG. Here since the ovarian mass is extremely tender, it has probably undergone torsion and a Doppler should be done to diagnose torsion followed by an urgent cystectomy
Complications of ovarian masses in pregnancy
• Rupture
• Torsion
• Hemorrhage
• Obstruction in labour
Management
• <5 cm: follow up
• 5-9 cm: cystectomy in case of torsion, rupture, suspicion of malignancy, sudden increase in size during follow up
• >=10 cm: elective cystectomy in second trimester
• NOTE: red degeneration is a complication of fibroid in pregnancy
• Since cervical os is closed, it is not a case of inevitable abortion

questions.text: Episiotomy was done during the assisted vaginal delivery, which extends and involves upto 40 percent of the External anal sphincter. Degree of perineal tear here is ?
questions.solution:
• First degree- injury to vaginal mucosa
  • Second degree- injury to perineal muscles
  • Third degree- Anal sphincter torn:
  • a. <50% EAS
  • b. >50% EAS
  • c. EAS & IAS
  • Fourth degree- involvement of rectal mucosa

questions.text: Patient has palpitations and episodic Hypertension and diaphoresis. Which of the following tests must be done to identify?
questions.solution:
• Given history is suggestive of Pheochromocytoma
  • C/F of pheochromocytoma [mnemonic: PHD]
    • Palpitations
    • Hypertension
    • Diaphoresis
  • Urinary catecholamines/ derivative of catecholamines I.e metanephrines/ VMA [Vanillyl Mandelic acid] levels are done for diagnosis

Other options

  • Urinary 5HIAA is done for Carcinoid tumor/ syndrome
  • HVA is derivative of dopamine. Not done routinely Chromogranin A is related to immunohistochemistry component of pheochromocytoma, but it isn’t a diagnostic test

questions.text: Patient has had RTA and his GCS= 9/15. There is no external site of bleeding visible. IVF fluid resuscitation was done, and patient is still hypotensive. Which of the following is least likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
• If the pt. remains hypotensive even after IV fluid resusitation is done, its clinical interpretation is that there is an area where substantial amount of bleeding is present.
  • I.e Large compartment internal bleeding is present.
  • Hemothorax, splenic rupture & retroperitoneal bleed contribute to large compartment internal bleeding
  • If splenic rupture occurs, despite of fluid resusitation patient would be hypotensive
  • Retroperitonial space is a space where blood can accumulate
  • In Hemothorax, blood gets accumulated in chest cavity . So, BP crashes.
  • Subdural hematoma is relatively small compartment bleeding I.e max of 100ml
    • Duramater is a limited space. So despite of hematoma, it’s not going to cause unrecordable BP in the patient
    • Bleeding will stop on its own due to tamponade effect.
    • Head injury leads to Cushing’s reflex, which results in increased BP & decreased heart rate.

questions.text: Mackler’s triad is seen in ?
questions.solution:
Above clinical scenario is suggestive of diagnosis ofspontaneous perforation of the esophagus.

Aka BOERHAAVE Syndrome

  • Caused by Forceful vomiting Repeated vomiting

Clinical features

Characterized by Mackler’s triad

  • Thoracic Pain
  • Vomiting
  • Cervical subcutaneous emphysema

Investigation

  • On CXR – Hydropneumothorax
  • IOC for Dx - Water soluble contrast esophagogram (Gastrograffin > Hypaque)

questions.text: Charcot’s triad include all of the following, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
• Charcot’s triad – abdominal pain + jaundice + fever.
  • Seen in Cholangitis.
  • For cholangitis to occur, the 2 essential factors are obstruction & infection.

Predisposing factorsfor cholangitis:

  1. CBD stones (M.C)
  2. Stricture
  3. Cholangiocarcinoma
  4. Choledochal cyst
  5. Worms
  • M.C organism responsible for CBD is E. coli > Klebsiella.
  • M.C symptom → fever + chills.
  • Inadequate treatment causes Reynold’s pentad → Charcot’s triad + shock + mental status changes.

questions.text: which is the most common location of Visceral arterial aneurysm?
questions.solution:
• Most common site of splanchnic aneurysm is splenic artery
  • Most common site of visceral arterial aneurysm is splenic artery

  • MC site of peripheral aneurysm: Popliteal aneurysm
  • Degenerative aneurysms (caused by atherosclerosis) are MC AAA (90%)

questions.text: A carcinoma that arises because of radiation exposure ?
questions.solution:
• Follicular ca:- Seen in iodine deficient areas
    • M/C malignancy in long standing goiter
    • M/c malignancy in multinodular goiter
  • Papillary ca: Seen in iodine sufficient areas

questions.text: An infant is brought to a Pediatric OPD because her wet diapers turn black when they are exposed to air. Physical examination: normal. Urine: positive for reducing substance and on testing with ferric chloride. A deficiency of which of the following would result in this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Alkaptonuria:
    • Autosomal recessive disorder
    • Deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.
    • In infants: urine turns dark brown or black on exposure to air due to oxidation of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: CLD patient presented to OPD with fever and gross abdominal distention. On abdominal examination tenderness is elicited. Ascitic fluid reveals presence of 500 cells/ cu.mm. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• CLD results in cirrhosis, which leads to ascites
  • Fever + tenderness + increased ascitic fluid cells is suggestive of Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis
  • If a pt. comes to the hospital with massive ascites, paracentesis should be done as soon as possible, as bacteria in the intestine can migrate into this area & cause infection, resulting in spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
  • If we find > 250 PMN/cu.mm2 in ascitic fluid, think of Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis
  • IV ceftriaxone can be used for treatment

Other options

  • Large volume paracentesis is done in Refractory Ascites I.e ascites persisting even after max dose of diuretics I.e Spironolactone 400mg, Furosemide 160mg
  • IV albumin plus midodrine is given in Hepato-renal syndrome I.e cirrhosis pt. having oliguria, anuria, puffiness of the face & renal shutdown
  • IV Octreotide is given for bleeding varices

questions.text: Most common cause of Post partum hemorrhage ?
questions.solution:
Atonicity causes about 80% of PPH.
Causes of PPH:
1. Uterine atonicity (m/c)
2. Injury to any part of genital tract
3. Coagulopathy (von Willebrand's disease)
4. Retained tissues - (Causes secondary PPH)

questions.text: True about Systemic inflammatory Response syndrome (SIRS) :
questions.solution:
SIRS

Two or more of the following:

  1. Temperature (core) >38°C or <36°C
  2. Heart rate >90 beats/minQ
  3. Respiratory rate >20 breaths/minQ for patients spontaneously ventilating or a PaCO2 <32 mm HgQ
  4. WBC count >12,000 cells/mm3 or <4000Q cells/mm3 or >10% immature (band) cells in the peripheral blood smear

questions.text: A 7 year old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of difficulty in breathing. Physical examination findings showed that the patient was in distress, breathing through mouth. He also had typical adenoid facies. All of the following are indications of adenoidectomy, except?

questions.text: Test for ovarian reserve?

4. Serum anti mullerian hormone (AMH): It is produced by the granulosa cells of the preantral small follicles

6. Serum estradiol levels

questions.text: A 40 year old patient presented with the following clinical finding. What might be the underlying cause of this feature?

Apparent leukonychia

questions.text: A 30 year old female presented with hoarseness of voice. The patient is a teacher by profession. Laryngoscopy revealed presence of bilateral swelling fixed over the free margins of the vocal cords. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vocal nodule / Singer’s nodule / Screamer’s nodule

  • Due to chronic misuse of voice
  • Seen in teachers and singers
  • B/L, sessile (fixed on free margins)
  • Most common site at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd (area of maximum vibration)
  • C/F – Hoarseness of voice

Treatment

  • Speech therapy
  • PPI (LPR’s a major contributor)
  • Early/soft nodules – with speech therapy and PPI
  • Late/hard nodules – Rx of choice – Speech therapy with PPI, Surgery

questions.text: Which of the following agents have adverse effect on the health of the liver?

Effects on Liver

questions.text: Curling ulcer is ?
questions.solution:

    • Stress induced gastritis (or) Haemorrhagic Gastritis
    • M/C site → stomach
    • M/C site in stomach → Fundus > Body > Antrum

Two types of stress ulcers:

  1. CUSHING ULCERS → Head injury
  2. CURLING ULCERS → BURNS

questions.text: A 30 year old female presented with conductive hearing loss in both ears. The patient addressed that her hearing gets better when she goes outside of her house. Pure tone audiometry showed a dip at 2000 Hz. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Otosclerosis

1) Pure Tone Audiometry

  • Otosclerosis is a disease of conductive hearing loss
  • CARHART’s NOTCH → Dip present at 2000 Hz in bone conduction seen.
  • BOILER 'S NOTCH → In NIHL dip at 4000 Hz in bone conduction seen.
Disease AB GAP
SOM 25-30dB
TM perforation 10-40dB
TM perforation + Ossicular chain erosion 45dB
TM intact + Ossicular discontinuity 54dB
Otosclerosis Upto 60 dB

2) Impedance Audiometry: As curve seen

3) Stapedial reflex is absent b/c stapes footplate is fixed.

Paracussis willisii

  • Pt. hears better in noisy places
  • Also seen in pts. with B/L CHL.

Tx

  • Stapedectomy
    • Remove stapes & graft is placed at the oval window & piston is placed.
    • Risk of SNHL present
  • Stapedotomy (RxOC) → Hole made in stapes footplate and anchored with piston.

questions.text: 8-month-old child with diarrhea was given potassium correction. But Potassium value is not improving and floppiness in child is noted. Which of the following is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
• Hypokalemia & hypomagnesemia can coexists
  • Thus, if there isn’t any improvement with potassium correction, give magnesium to the pt.
  • Mostly in malnourished children/ in children with diarrhea for long term basis, magnesium deficiency can be present
  • Once the magnesium deficiency is corrected, potassium levels come to normal

questions.text: True about tamoxifen:-

Effects of tamoxifen
Tamoxifen is an S.E.R.M (selective estrogen receptor modulator)

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis of a chronic smoker with progressive deterioration over time
questions.solution:

Other options

    • I.e White --> Blue --> Red
    • It is MC seen in women
  • Fournier Gangrene involves scrotal skin & is caused by anaerobes
  • Ainhum is characterized by auto-amputation [seen in old and Negro descents]

questions.text: All the below structures are removed in radical neck dissection, EXCEPT?

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the ER for evaluation of altered behavior and cyanosis. On examination, he has flaccid muscle tone and is taking shallow respirations. No preceding fever, cough, coryza, rash, or new medications; uncomplicated pre- and antenatal course. questions.text: The genotype is found to be 46,XX, after the physical examination of a newborn child whose genitalia appear to be female, but masculinized. Most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Adrenogenital syndrome/ congenital virilizing hyperplasia:
    • Deficiency in the pathway leading to cortisol synthesis → inability to synthesize cortisol → high levels of ACTH and ACTH-releasing factor production from hypothalamus → hypertrophy of fetal adrenal cortex → excessive production of androgens by fetal adrenal → leads to masculinization of female genitalia.

questions.text: Gardasil vaccine for HPV involves all of the following strains, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
More than 90% of CIN is attributed to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
Only certain types of HPV cause high-grade intraepithelial lesions and cancer
(HPV-16, -18, -31, -33, -35, -39, -45, -51, -52, -56, -58, -59, -68).
Type 16 is the most common form of HPV found in invasive cancer and in CIN 2 and CIN3;
HPV-18 is more specific than HPV-16 for invasive tumors i.e. HPV 18 is the most malignant.
Please note:
Usually, HPV infections do not persist. Most women who are exposed have no clinical evidence of disease, and the infection is eventually suppressed or eliminated.
VACCINES FOR HPV :-

  • CERVARIX:- 16 & 18
  • GARDASIL:- 6,11,16,18
  • GARDASIL-9:- An additional five high risk subtypes(HPV 31/33/45/52/58)

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented with complaints of epigastric boring type of pain for the past 3 days, associated with vomiting and fever. Xray abdomen was done, shows colon cut off sign. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Acute pancreatitis

  • In acute pancreatitis due to damaged duct and acini there is extravasation of pancreatic enzymes such as lipase into the peritoneal cavity.
  • This causes digestion of fat of greater omentum which in turn leads to formation of fatty acid & glycerol.
  • Free fatty acid combines with calcium and leads to formation of chalky whitedeposits known as “SAPNOFICATION”
  • Patients of pancreatitis presents with hypocalcaemia as calcium is used up for saponification.
  • The pancreatic enzymes that entered into peritoneal cavity also causes Paralytic ileus

X-ray findings of Paralytic ileus:

  1. Gasless abdomen
  2. Ground Glass appearance
  3. Sentinel loop
  4. Colon cut-off sign

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents with Frequent episodes of menstruation usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
• Oligomenorrhoea → Infrequent and irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occuring at intervals of more than 35 days
  • Polymenorrhoea → Frequent episodes of mentruation usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less
  • Menorrhagia → Increased menstrual flow/Increased duration at regular cycles
  • Hypomenorrhoea → Scanty bleeding and shorter days of bleeding
  • Metrorrhagia → Irregular bleeding in between the cycles
  • Menometrorrhagia → Increased menstrual flow as well as irregular bleeding between the cycles

questions.text: In carcinoma cervix, level 3 group of lymph nodes comprises?
questions.solution:
Levels of lymph nodes dissected in lymphadenectomy done for cervical cancer, also suggests the lymphatic spread of the cancer

  • Level 1: Parametrial, obturator, external iliac
  • Level 2: common iliac, presacral
  • Level 3: para-aortic,para-caval

Therefore, parametrial, obturator and external iliac group of lymph nodes are involved first, while involvement of common iliac nodes indicates higher chances of metastatic spread.

questions.text: A 17-year male patient presented to opd with deafness and blood in urine. He is k/c/o CKD and is on treatment for that. His maternal uncle has the same disease. He was referred to ophthalmology department to look for the presence of Lenticonus. Clinical diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Positive family H/o - CKD, SNHL, hematuria - Points Dx of Alport’s syndrome
  • COL4A gene defect
  • Also associated with lenticonus
    • Good pasture syndrome is a autoimmune condition mainly presents with hemoptysis & hematuria
    • IgA nephropathy - leading cause of microscopic hematuria
    • Tubulointerstitial nephritis - presents with salt wasting, no manifestation of deafness or hematuria.

questions.text: GH hormone levels are high but IGF-1 levels are low. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:

  • In GH deficiency, GHRH deficiency & GHRH receptor defect; GH is decreased

questions.text: Tall T waves, wide QRS and prolonged PR interval is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Given history is suggestive of hyperkalemia
  • Increased levels of Potassium levels causes slowing of the heart, resulting in
    • Tall tented T-waves
    • Wide QRS complex
    • Prolonged PR-interval
    • Vertical height of p-wave gradually begins to reduce & may finally disappear

  • In Hypokalemia,
    • T-wave becomes smaller & then negative k/a T-wave inversion
  • Hypo & hypernatremia don’t produce any ECG findings. They cause CNS manifestations
    • Sodium is <125 or >160, contribute to cerebral edema & seizures

questions.solution:
Seborrheic keratosis

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with a history of headache and blurred vision in both eyes for the past four months. Fundoscopy revealed bilateral pale optic discs. Intraocular pressure was 20 mm Hg. T2W MRI showed periventricular white mater hyperintensities perpendicular to ventricles. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Multiple Sclerosis (Auto immune)

  • Autoimmune destruction of myelin formed
  • Periventricular white mater hyperintensities perpendicular to ventricles – DAWSON Fingers
  • Involvement of Calloso – septal interface.
  • Open ring / Horseshoe enhancement is suggestive of demyelination.

White mater Leukodystrophy – Alexander disease

  • White mater dystrophy of bilateral frontal lobes
  • Associated with Megalencephaly (Large skull)

Adrenoleukodystrophy
• White mater of Bilateral occipital lobes is involved

Krabbes disease / Globoid cell leukodystrophy
• Involvement of B/L thalami.

questions.text: True about Gastrinoma, EXCEPT ?

choices.text: Rarely seen in MEN I Neoplasms

questions.solution:
• Most common functional & malignant NET in MEN 1: Gastrinoma Most common functional Neuroendocrine tumor: Insulinoma
  • Gastrinoma is the most common islet cell tumor in patients with MEN I. Patients with MEN I usually have multiple gastrinomas. MEN I is characterised by parathyroid, pituitary and pancreatic (or duodenal ) tumours

Gastrinoma

  • Gastrinoma is an endocrine tumour that secretes gastrin which causes a syndrome called Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES) characterised by acid hypersecretion and peptic ulceration
  • Although most of the ulcers are solitary, multiple ulcers in atypical locations that fail to respond to antacids should raise suspicion of ZES
  • Gastrin levels >1000 pg/mL is suggestive of gastrinoma. But this is not specific as gastrin levels are elevated in other conditions like pernicious anemia, atrophic gastritis , etc. In equivocal cases, a secretin stimulation test is helpful
  • In 70% to 90% of patients, the primary gastrinoma is found in Passaro’s triangle, an area defined by a triangle with points located at the junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct, the second and third portion of the duodenum, the neck and body of the pancreas
  • The test of choice is SSTR (octreotide) scintigraphyin combination with CT. The octreotide scan is more sensitive than CT, locating about 85% of gastrinomas and detecting tumours <1cm
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is particularly helpful in localising tumours in the pancreatic head or duodenal wall, where gastrinomas are usually <1cm in size
  • A combination of octreotide scan and EUS detects >90% of gastrinomas
  • One fourth of gastrinomas occur in association with MEN1 syndrome. Approximately 50% of gastrinomas metastasize lymph nodes or the liver and are therefore considered malignant. Treatment involves complete resection of tumour

questions.text: All the following pubertal changes are influenced by estrogen, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Presence of Estrogen in a pubertal girl stimulates the

  1. formation of Breast development,
  2. Production of cervical mucus
  3. Vaginal cornification.
  4. As estrogen levels increase, menses begins.
  5. Ovarian estrogen production late in puberty is at least in part responsible for termination of the pubertal growth spurt, thereby determining adult height.

Hair growth during puberty is caused by androgens from the adrenal gland and,later, the ovary

questions.text: Young Female complaints of feeling weakness during blinking of eye, diplopia, and having dysphagia. The symptoms are increased at end of the day. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Neurological features with diurnal variation is suggestive of Myasthenia gravis
  • Patterson Kelly Syndrome presents with Dysphagia + Iron deficiency anemia + koilonychia. Eye manifestations are never seen
  • Thyroid disease presents with heat/ cold intolerance
  • Scleroderma presents with Dysphagia + Raynaud’s phenomenon + Pulmonary artery hypertension. Fibrosis is seen in all the organs of the body. Ocular manifestations are absent in this
  • When a question is given on a female with ocular manifestations, think of Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: A 27-year-old female on oestrogen containing OCP’s for birth control came to eye OPD complaining about sudden painless los of vision. On examination the image given below was obtained of the fundus. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image is showing mild venous congestion, tortuosity, and multiple dot-blot, superficial flame shaped haemorrhage suggestive of non-ischemic type of CRVO.

Predisposing factors:

  • DM
  • Hypertension
  • Arteriosclerosis
  • Hypercoagulability
  • OCP users
  • Hyper viscosity of blood
